In the treatise, the sixteen truths are explained. The general question is:
Are there sixteen things or sixteen names?
The answer:

The master who explains the meaning of VipaÅ›yandin's extensive explanation says there are sixteen things, so he establishes the sixteen names. Since the substance actually exists, it is called a thing.
The master who explains the meaning of the SÅ«tra on the Practice of Renunciation says there are sixteen names, but there are only seven things. The truth of suffering has four aspects,
namely impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self. The truths of origination, cessation, and the path each have one aspect, totaling seven.

The Buddha originally taught the SÅ«tra on the Practice of Renunciation to explain various meanings. After the Buddha's passing, Ä€nanda, KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra, and others recited what they had previously heard to explain the meanings in the sÅ«tras, just as the disciples composed treatises to explain the sÅ«tras. Therefore, it is called the SÅ«tra on the Practice of Renunciation.

Since it is a transmission, it does not say VibhÄá¹£Ä of the sÅ«tras.
Now, first relying on the previous explanation.
Because it belongs to conditions, it is called impermanent. Conditioned dharmas have no power to arise by themselves, they arise only by relying on conditions.
Like a young child who cannot stand up by itself, it can only stand up by relying on others to support it.
What are called conditions are precisely craving and karma.
These two dharmas must be complete before the five aggregates can be born.
Karma can produce results. Although it can produce, if there is no craving and attachment to the place where it should be born, the result will also not arise.
It is like the earth, water, etc. can produce grain sprouts. If no one works to place the grain seeds in the ground, the sprouts will never grow.
Before craving and karma arise, the result is non-existent.
When the causes and conditions of craving, love, and karma come together, the effect is then produced, and there is existence.
If the power of karma is exhausted, the effect will cease and return to non-existence.
This is simply before and after, with no connection between before and after, because it belongs to conditions.
It is said to belong to conditions and is therefore called impermanent.
Because it has the nature of oppression, it is called suffering.
There are two kinds of oppression: oppression that goes against and oppression that goes along.
If it is oppression that goes against, it is towards the Buddha's disciples.
The Buddha's disciples always give rise to fear in the midst of birth and death. A sutra compares it to:
It is like a sharp sword on fire, with flames dazzling the eyes. If someone holds it to the side, wanting to use it to harm, in every thought there will always be great fear.
The Buddha's disciples' fear of birth and death is also like this.
This is the meaning of going against below.
But birth, old age, sickness, death, and so forth, always oppress and therefore it is suffering.
If it is oppression that goes along, it is towards ordinary people.
Ordinary beings' attachment to birth and death is the meaning of following.

It is like two brothers, the elder brother loves the younger brother very much, but the younger brother always annoys the elder brother. Although the elder brother suffers from the annoyance, he still loves the younger brother.
Ordinary beings' attachment to birth and death, although they suffer, they still love and cling to it, therefore, it is called suffering because of its nature of oppression.
In order to counteract the view of mine, it is called emptiness.
Ordinary beings grasp at all dharmas and say they are mine. Now, it is clarified that all are not mine. In order to counteract this view, it is called emptiness.
In order to counteract the view of self, it is called no-self.

Ordinary beings grasp at the five skandhas and so forth as the self. Now, it is clarified that all dharmas are without self. In order to counteract this view, no-self is taught. These four are the truth of suffering.
Next, the four names of the truth of accumulation are explained.
Because of the principle of the dharma of seeds, it is called cause, which can give rise to effects.
This dharma of seeds has four meanings, which is its principle.

The four meanings are: First, if the seeds are destroyed, they cannot produce. It is like taking seeds and grinding them to destroy them. Even with all the conditions, they can no longer produce sprouts.
Craving and other afflictions are also the seeds that produce results. If they are destroyed by the path, even with the remaining conditions, they can no longer produce results.
Second, even though the conditions are complete, the seeds cannot produce sprouts because the seeds have been stored for a long time.

The production of results by craving and other afflictions is also like this. ÅšrÄvakas practice for sixty eons, pratyekabuddhas practice for a hundred eons, and buddhas practice for three incalculable eons.

The three vehicles of beings, before they have aroused the mind [of enlightenment], in the state of icchantika, give rise to afflictions such as craving, and the karma produced by afflictions has not yet received the fruits it will bring. From the time of practice onward, they pass through many periods of time, and merit and wisdom become increasingly profound and vast, overshadowing the power and efficacy of past causes. Even with other conditions present, they cannot produce fruits.
The MahÄvastu says:
Ninety-eight delusions give rise to one affliction, and one affliction gives rise to ninety-eight delusions.
For example, craving gives rise to ninety-eight delusions, and all of them can give rise to craving.
Third, even with other conditions present, it does not produce sprouts, just as planting in spring will produce but planting in winter will not.
Causes that have lost their time also cannot produce fruits, just as Aá¹…gulimÄla, due to ignorance, took two thousand lives, and upon death would certainly have entered hell;

Yet they manifest the attainment of arhatship in this body. Because the previously committed evil has been eliminated, even with the presence of other conditions, it will not produce any further fruits.
Fourth, even if the conditions are not destroyed, not old, and not lost, the seed will still not sprout if the conditions are incomplete.
Just as the conditions such as earth, water, and human effort are incomplete, so the seed cannot sprout.

The arising of the effect from the cause is also like this. Even if it has not been destroyed, has not passed a long time, and has not been lost, if the conditions are incomplete, it will not be able to produce the effect.
If sentient beings create karma that can lead to the arising of effects, three things must be present:
First, being close to good spiritual friends; second, having a mind of faith and understanding; third, making effort in evil deeds.
These three things must be sought against this. If the three things are absent, the conditions are incomplete, and the effect cannot be obtained. Therefore, the Ugly Sutra says:
If sentient beings wish to be reborn among humans, but the conditions for creating karma are incomplete, they will then experience the effects among animals and other realms.
If one commits evil karma, one should be reborn in the animal realm, but due to incomplete conditions, one experiences the results in the human realm.
It is like an arhat who, although possessing various karmas, has eliminated all afflictions and has no karma accompanied by afflictions, so it cannot lead to rebirth.

It is also like a non-returner who attains cessation, whose karma is exhausted but whose craving is not yet exhausted, so they cannot be reborn in the form realm and are reborn in the intermediate state.

It is also like one who attains the first fruit, who then gives rise to afflictions to be eliminated by the path of cultivation. Although they possess karma and afflictions born from afflictions, because they have eliminated the afflictions to be eliminated by the path of seeing, they no longer use new karma to take rebirth.
The principle of seeds in the world must have four aspects in order for a sprout to grow.
The principle of seeds of craving and karma is also like this. It must have four aspects in order to be able to produce results. Producing results is called cause.
Question:
What is the correct seed, karma or afflictions?
The answer is:
Afflictions are the correct [seed].
Afflictions give rise to karma, but karma cannot give rise to afflictions, because afflictions are the root.
Moreover, there is karma without afflictions, which definitely cannot lead to rebirth;
there are afflictions without karma, which can lead to rebirth in the intermediate state.
Second, it is called accumulation because it manifests.

There are two meanings of manifestation: First, craving and karma correspond to each other, causing the fruit to be born. Before it is born, the fruit is not yet manifest; when it is born, it is manifested.
Second, craving can manifest the object. The object is actually contemptible, but craving turns the mind and considers the object to be good, thus manifesting the object as good.

For example, a single woman is observed by three kinds of consciousness. An ordinary person sees her and considers her to be a desirable object; a tiger or wolf sees her and considers her to be food; a sage sees her and considers her to be a skeleton.
It is called a bone-store, this is knowing in accordance with the object.
It is called lovable and edible, both because this object appears due to craving and love.
Because the object that appears due to craving and love is the place where one should be born, one gives rise to attachment in it, and thus karma can produce results;
If these two appearances do not exist, the result cannot be produced.
This clarification of the two kinds of appearances is to explain the meaning of accumulation.
Non-Buddhists say that all dharmas are produced by only one cause, that the one cause of the Lord of the World produces all things.
Now, in order to refute this view, it is clarified that only when many conditions gather can a result be produced.
Even though many conditions gather, if they cannot cause the result to arise, they are not causes. Only when they gather and cause the result to arise can they be causes.
The two kinds of appearances also clarify the meaning of gathering and also clarify the meaning of causing the result to arise, therefore, appearance is used to explain accumulation.
It is like a potter using clay, rope, water, and other conditions coming together to produce a single pot.
Because it can pull out the fruit and make it accomplished, it is called a condition.
A cause directly produces the fruit, while a condition can make the fruit arise and cause the complete accomplishment of the karmic retribution for one lifetime.
Next, explaining the four names of the truth of cessation.
The exhaustion of the five aggregates and non-arising is called cessation, based on the karmic retribution to speak.
The present five aggregates are exhausted, and the future five aggregates do not arise, so it is called cessation.
Now, the name of cessation is taken as the essence of the unconditioned.
The truth of cessation itself takes the unconditioned as its essence, not taking the cessation and non-arising of the five aggregates as its essence.
The cessation and non-arising of the five aggregates are in the three time periods, while the essence of the truth of cessation is unconditioned, not a dharma of the three time periods.

The cessation and non-arising of the five aggregates in the three time periods are like the five aggregates of ÅšÄriputra, MaudgalyÄyana, and others, which are in the past and have ceased without arising;
The five aggregates of ordinary beings will cease without arising in the future;
If the five aggregates of a present noble person are present, they are extinguished but not produced.

Among unconditioned dharmas there are no five aggregates. The five aggregates are not produced in this [unconditioned dharma]. Therefore, the meaning of extinction and non-production is used to refer to the unconditioned.
Moreover, when the five aggregates are extinguished, destroyed, and not produced, one then realizes and attains this unconditioned dharma.
Because the meaning of extinction and non-production is used to refer to the unconditioned, the unconditioned is called extinction.
Because it can extinguish the three fires, it is called tranquil.
There are two kinds of three fires:
First, desire, anger, and delusion are the three fires.
These three have three meanings, so they are called fires:

First, they can burn all the wholesome roots of sentient beings. Second, these three afflictions can make the mind hot, which means they can burn the mind. Third, they can burn the three realms, so they are called fires.
These three afflictions are found throughout the three realms, and arise from the six sense objects, six sense faculties, and six consciousnesses.
Because of these three afflictions, one cannot attain peace and happiness.
The three afflictions are like fire that can burn, and the faculties, objects, and consciousnesses are like firewood that is burned.
Question:
The upper realms are without anger, so how can it be said that there is anger now?
Answer:

Ordinary beings who are born in the upper realms are fully endowed with the afflictions of the path of seeing. They are not without in the upper realms, but because they cannot arise, it is said that they are absent.
The present statement that they exist is made from the perspective of principle.
Second, taking the three kinds of suffering as the three fires.

These three kinds of suffering can burn sentient beings and prevent them from attaining happiness. If in the desire realm, then all three kinds of suffering are present. In the form realm, then the suffering of change and the suffering of conditioned existence are present. In the formless realm, then only the suffering of conditioned existence is present.

The three kinds of suffering are precisely the three calamities. The suffering of suffering is the fire calamity, the suffering of change is the water calamity, and the suffering of conditioned existence is the wind calamity.

Having these two kinds of three fires then causes agitation. In order to extinguish these two kinds of three fires, it is called tranquil. Because there are no three kinds of suffering, it is called wonderful.
The three kinds of suffering refer to the three kinds of suffering of birth, old age, and death.
These three sufferings are equal and universal in the three realms, so these three sufferings are biased and said to be the three hardships.
All three realms have birth, so there is the suffering of birth.

If it is the desire realm, then there is the aging of white hair and wrinkled face. The six heavens and the form realm do not have the appearance of this aging, but there is still the meaning of change, just as a painting is clear and lovely when first done, but after a long time the colors fade and thin. The form bodies of the upper realms also have this meaning, and this is called aging.

The mind of the formless realm also has aging. When the retribution is about to end, the function of the mind changes. The mind of concentration in the past was firm, but at the end the mind of concentration is weak and always wants to fall back.
Therefore, all three realms have the suffering of aging.
All three realms end, so they all have the suffering of death.

The reason it is called adverse is that the nature of ordinary beings always seeks comfort and happiness. Therefore, they cultivate worldly goodness in the hope of attaining happy rewards, but these three calamities cause them to experience suffering. Therefore, the three sufferings are called the three adversities.
Within the unconditioned, there are no these three adversities, and therefore it is called wonderful.
Question:
When being born in the upper realms, one does not suffer by oneself. Why is it called suffering?
Answer:
It is not necessarily called suffering because one experiences painful feelings when born. It is called suffering because birth is the root of suffering.
Since the unconditioned is unborn, it is therefore without suffering. Since birth and death involve birth, they therefore involve suffering. Therefore, birth is called suffering.
Just as hell is the name of a place, and the place itself is not suffering, but because the place gives rise to suffering, hell is called suffering.
Question:
Among the three kinds of suffering, which kind of suffering is the suffering of birth?
Answer:

If painful feelings are born, it is the suffering of suffering. If pleasant feelings are born, it is the suffering of change. If neutral feelings are born, it is the suffering of conditioned existence.
In the desire realm, birth is accompanied by all three kinds of suffering;
In the form realm, birth is accompanied by two kinds of suffering, namely the suffering of change and the suffering of formations;
In the formless realm, there is only the suffering of formations.

Aging is also accompanied by all three kinds of suffering. If pleasant feelings change into suffering, it is the suffering of suffering; if suffering changes into pleasant feelings, or pleasant feelings change into pleasant feelings, it is the suffering of change; if pleasant feelings change into neutral feelings, it is the suffering of formations.
The suffering of death in the three realms is also accompanied by all three kinds of suffering. It can be understood by analogy with the above.
Question:
How many kinds of suffering are taught in the sutras?
Answer:
It is said that there are innumerable kinds of suffering.
Apart from the eight kinds of suffering taught here, there are other kinds of suffering that are distinguished, but only seven kinds of suffering are mentioned.
The old eight kinds of suffering do not mention the suffering of illness. After explaining the seven kinds of suffering, it says and so on for the rest of the sufferings.

The reason why the suffering of illness is not mentioned is because the suffering of illness is only found in the human realm of the desire realm, and is not universal in the heavens of the desire realm, so it is not mentioned.
The reason there is no suffering from illness in the heavens is that illness arises from internal and external conditions.
Externally, it is caused by uneven cold and heat, and improper diet and daily life, leading to the suffering of illness.
Internally, it may be caused by excessive walking weakening the four elements, or excessive sitting weakening the four elements. Because the four elements are weak, illness occurs.

In the upper realms, there are no external conditions of uneven cold and heat, or improper diet and daily life. Internally, the four elements are strong, and there are no conditions of excessive walking or sitting. Therefore, there is no suffering from illness.
A twisted explanation also has the meaning of illness.

The six heavens engage in sexual activity, and may not eat for three days up to seven days. Before seven days, if they do not die, their four elements become weak, which can also be called the suffering of illness.
Question:
What about the other four sufferings?
Answer:

If the five aggregates are common to the three realms, then the suffering of seeking but not obtaining, the suffering of separation from what is loved, and the suffering of encountering what is hated.
These three sufferings do not exist in the two upper realms, because they are called self-abiding retribution, and there is no mixed dwelling in one place, so these three sufferings do not exist.
The six heavens in the desire realm all have them.

The lower heavens wish and enjoy the higher heavens, but cannot attain them, so they give rise to the suffering of not obtaining, which is the suffering of not obtaining.ğŸ”½Fighting with the asuras is the suffering of being with what is disliked.
When fighting and losing, being bound and defeated by the asuras is the suffering of separation from what is loved.
Liberation from all losses is called permanent separation.
All losses are causes, conditions, and retribution.
Causes are afflictions, conditions are karma, and the five aggregates that are received are retribution. These three are faults.
Permanently liberated from these three, not temporarily liberated, is called permanent separation.
Question:
Why are afflictions called causes and karma called conditions?
Answer:
Afflictions are the seeds that directly pull one into rebirth, so they are called causes.
If there were no afflictions, even if there were karma, it would not be able to pull one into rebirth.
If there were no karma but afflictions, one could still be reborn in the intermediate state.
If the afflictions are exhausted, even if karma can adorn the fruition, it is still due to the afflictions that karma is produced and the fruition is obtained.
Next, explaining the four names of the truth of the path.
In it, practicing is called the path.
There are two explanations:
One says that the knowledge of exhaustion and non-production is the practice, and precepts, concentration, and wisdom are what is practiced.

From the knowledge of the factors of suffering up to the inferential knowledge of the path, the twelve minds all eliminate afflictions, which is the knowledge of exhaustion, and the thirteenth mind is the knowledge of non-production.
Precepts have outflows, but they are originally without outflows. Because the two knowledges practice them, they become without outflows.
Concentration is also like this.
Knowledge is of three kinds: heard, contemplated, and cultivated.
Cultivated wisdom also has defilements and is free from defilements, and it becomes free from defilements by the practice of both knowledges.
The practice of the knowledge of exhaustion is when the knowledge of the flow of suffering is present, and the eightfold noble path is complete.
Precepts and concentration, which originally have defilements, now become free from defilements by the practice of the knowledge of exhaustion.
The knowledge of exhaustion is of two kinds: one is right view, and the other is right thought.
Although they both contemplate impermanence, there is coarseness and subtlety. Right view is subtle, and right thought is coarse, but these two can mutually give rise to each other.

If right view is taken as the knowledge of exhaustion, it can also be said that right view becomes free from defilements, and in the end, it is by the knowledge of exhaustion that wisdom becomes free from defilements.
If this meaning is clarified, then in one moment, it is practiced by the knowledge of exhaustion, and thus precepts, concentration, and wisdom become free from defilements.
Because of their different natures, they can occur simultaneously, and so it is for all arhats.

If one uses right view to look at right view, and right thought to look at right thought, then they cannot occur simultaneously. The previous right view must make the later right view become uncontaminated.
Right thought is also like this. Within one moment, they cannot occur together, because two dharmas cannot have the same nature.
If the meaning is explained like this, then wisdom at different times is explained as being practiced by the knowledge of exhaustion, and all the way up to arhatship is like this;
it is practiced by the knowledge of non-arising, and all the way up to arhatship is like this.

As for the precepts, concentration, and wisdom that are made uncontaminated by the practice of the knowledge of non-arising, the ten subsequent minds of seeing the truths have the subsequent ten minds belonging to the fruit.

If a srota-Äpanna person contemplates with twelve minds, then it is the knowledge of non-arising that makes the precepts, concentration, and wisdom occur simultaneously, and the wisdom at different times becomes uncontaminated.
Question:
Isn't the view of the dharma of suffering itself the knowledge of non-arising? Why is it not mentioned?
Answer:
If the cognition of the doctrine of suffering is in relation to the cognition of the doctrine of suffering, it is also called the cognition of non-arising.
If it is in relation to the cognition of the class of suffering, it becomes the basis for the cognition of the class of suffering.
In the case of severing the afflictions of the upper realms, it belongs to the cognition of exhaustion.
Since it is not definitely the cognition of non-arising, it all belongs to the cognition of exhaustion.
Only the thirteenth mind is definite, and therefore it can be said to be the cognition of non-arising.

The second explanation says that morality, concentration, and wisdom become the practice of the uncontaminated mind, and therefore it is called the path. Then the uncontaminated mind is the practitioner, and morality, concentration, and wisdom are the practice. The cognition of exhaustion and non-arising are auxiliary mental factors.

The previous explanation differs from the latter interpretation. The phrase in the middle means that in the middle of morality, concentration, and wisdom, it is in accord with principle and is therefore called suchness. If discussed generally, it is in accord with the principle of the four characteristics and is therefore called suchness. If discussed specifically, it is in accord with the principle of neither annihilation nor permanence and is therefore called suchness.
Such wisdom that attains the principle, if it is destroyed by incorrect contemplation, it cannot make it become incorrect, therefore it is called suchness.
Because it is produced by right view, it is called right practice.

If a Å›rÄvaka hears the correct teaching spoken by a correct teacher, from the correct sound-name arises correct hearing, correct hearing gives rise to correct cultivation, practicing in this sequence is called what is done.

If it is a pratyekabuddha or a Buddha, then from correct contemplation arises correct cultivation, there is no meaning of correct hearing arising from correct sound-name, because the faculties of these two vehicles are sharp, they can contemplate and attain enlightenment by themselves.
Question:

Since the pratyekabuddhas and Buddhas all attain the ability to contemplate and cultivate wisdom by hearing the Dharma in the past, why is there no correct hearing giving rise to correct contemplation?
Answer:ğŸ”½It is not that they did not hear it in the past.
The present discussion is about the present matter, not about remembering what was heard in the past.
At that time, the teacher makes this statement and relies on this statement to give rise to the wisdom of reflection, and directly and uprightly contemplates to attain enlightenment by oneself;
The Å›rÄvakas must rely on the teacher's words to contemplate.
Because it permanently transcends, it is called going beyond.
There are two interpretations.
One interpretation says:
Because of wrong contemplation, afflictions arise. Afflictions give rise to karma, and karma gives rise to retribution. All of these are due to incorrect contemplation.
If uncontaminated wisdom arises, wisdom gives rise to precepts, concentration, and so forth. All of these are correct.
Correct and incorrect are opposites. Correctness permanently transcends incorrectness. It is not a temporary transcendence, but a permanent transcendence.
Another interpretation says:
Afflictions are inverted, and wisdom is non-inverted.
Inverted and non-inverted are opposites. Non-inversion permanently transcends inversion.
The former interpretation is extensive, while the latter is concise. Therefore, there are different uses.
The previous school also has another interpretation of the sixteen names, saying that because it is not the nature of permanence, it is called impermanent.
If unconditioned dharmas originally exist, they are permanently unborn and permanently non-abiding and non-ceasing.
Conditioned dharmas temporarily arise, temporarily abide, and temporarily cease. This is the nature of these dharmas, therefore it is called impermanent.
Because it arises from ignorance, it is suffering. Because it does not understand worldly affairs,
suffering is already close to not understanding worldly affairs, let alone not understanding the true and profound principle?
The root of suffering is even more suffering. Because of ignorance, one receives the retribution of birth and death, so there is no place in birth and death that is not suffering.
Because it is abandoned by people in the middle, it is called empty.
The six sense faculties are in the middle. The Buddha himself uses the analogy of a village for the six sense faculties.
Now, middle is like the middle of a village.
The self and person are not in this middle, therefore it is said to be abandoned by people.
Because it is abandoned by the self and person, it is called empty.
Because it is not self-sovereign, it is called non-self means that self-sovereignty has two meanings:
First, not relying on others is called self-sovereignty. If it does not arise, abide, or cease due to others, then it is self-sovereign;

Second, being able to do as one wishes is called self-sovereignty. If one wishes for fire to be cold, fire will immediately become cold, or if one wishes for water not to be wet, water will immediately not be wet, then this is self-sovereignty.
All conditioned dharmas rely on others, therefore they have arising, abiding, and ceasing, and also cannot be as one wishes.

If there is spiritual power that can transform, one must still rely on samÄdhi and other practices to cultivate in order to have this function. Since one cannot avoid relying on others, there is no self-sovereignty. Since there is no self-sovereignty, there is no self.
The principle of coming is called cause. Now, in order, it raises an analogy to explain it.
It takes seeds as an analogy.

It is like having seeds. Without relying on other conditions, they have the power to give rise to trees by themselves. The tree has not yet arisen, but since the seeds already have the power to give rise, they can cause the sprouts and so forth to come later.
The present part of karma is divided into four parts.

The first part is when one is about to perform good or evil karma, it has the power to induce results without relying on other conditions, and the results are still in the future until the end of life.
Since karma has the power to induce results, it can cause the results to come at a later time.
The principle of causing to come exists in the present, therefore it is called the cause.

As for the reason of arising and the reason of accumulation, the seed is the root of the tree, and the tree, sprouts, trunk, branches, leaves, etc. were originally in the future, but now the sprouts emerge from the soil inside the seed and rely on external conditions such as earth and water to finally emerge. As soon as the sprouts arise in the present, the seed immediately perishes.
Karma is also like this. It originally has the power to induce results, and the results are in the future.

When the present retribution is exhausted, one first experiences the intermediate state of existence and rebirth. As soon as the intermediate state of existence and rebirth arises, the first part of karma immediately ceases.

There is a principle of karma that can exit the intermediate state. It must be that the intermediate state arises as a result when the conditions gather. Therefore, it is said that because it exits according to principle, it is called arising.

As for because it moves and passes through, it is called the place of birth, the sprout appears first in the present. From the sprout, the stem grows. From the stem, up to the time before the flower appears, it is called moving and passing through.
The practitioner gradually increases and grows.
Having passed through the stage of the sprout, the stem just grows, and the sprout then disappears.

Karma is also like this. First, it experiences the sprout of the intermediate state. Having abandoned the sprout of the intermediate state, it experiences the correct birth. From the initial kalala up to the end of the seventh stage, it is called moving and passing through.

Because it gradually increases and grows, it is called moving. Because it passes through the stage of the intermediate state, it is called passing through. As soon as the kalala is born, the second stage disappears.

Because the kalala and so forth are born in sequence, it is called birth. Because this birth arises from karma, it is called karma. Because it is a place, it is called moving and passing through, and therefore it is called the karma of the place of birth.
The third stage has strong self-use.
If there is no karmic function, even if other conditions exist, the result will never arise.
The basis is called a condition.

The stem gradually grows first, but the flower has not yet bloomed. From the blooming of the flower until the formation of the fruit, and the fruit again giving rise to the future tree, all are called the basis.
The flower, fruit, and so forth all arise based on this stage of the seed.
As soon as the flower gives rise to the seed, the third stage of the seed immediately ceases.
Karma is also like this. From the initial kalala stage up to the seventh stage, it is unable to create the causes for birth and death or liberation.
From the second moment when the six sense faculties are complete, it is able to create the causes for birth and death and liberation. This stage is the fourth stage of karma.
From the beginning of this fourth stage, whether it is suffering and joy, evil or good, they all depend on the fourth stage of karma.
The fourth stage of karma is the basis, and is therefore called a condition.
As soon as the fourth stage of karma arises, the third stage of karma immediately ceases.

The fourth part of karma, self-use, is also strong. Since the effect has already arisen, relying on other conditions is weak. It is precisely because of the function of karma that the effect is fully obtained.

If karma in the second part induces the intermediate existence and birth, both causes and conditions are weak. Taking craving and love as the cause and karma as the condition, both things are weak. It cannot be fully compared to a seed, but only partially compared.
When performing karma, it is able to induce these four states of effect. Following the time period, there are differences, and there are these four kinds.
Based on these states, karma is divided into four parts.
Question:
How can one karma suddenly induce all these effects?
Answer:
In one instant, one karma is clarified, and it can also be divided into three parts in meaning. The previous and later parts are weak, and the middle part is clearly strong.
The weak induces the intermediate existence, and the strong induces the effect of birth.
If it is pure karma, it is initially strong and later weak.
Question:
How is the effect produced by karma different from a seed?
Answer:
This meaning is not the same.
If, according to the SarvÃ¢stivÄda school and other schools, it is explained that conditioned dharmas all cease moment by moment, one kind of seed is discussed in terms of ten moments.

If it is discussed in terms of the arising of characteristics within a single continuum, the first moment can give rise to the second moment, the second moment can give rise to the third, and so on, with the arising of characteristics always occurring in immediate succession.
The first [moment] arises and then ceases, not reaching the second [moment], so how can it give rise to the third?

If it is discussed in terms of the cause of the same type and the continuity [of the seed], the first moment of the cause of the same type can give rise to the second moment and so on up to the flowers and fruits. The cause of the same type includes this karmic result in the future.
The first moment ceases, and the second moment of the cause of the same type includes the third moment and so on of the result in the future. The subsequent moments are classified in the same way.
If there is no first moment of the seed as the basis, then there cannot be a second or third moment in succession.
The first moment of the seed is said to be able to produce.
The later fruits are called the homogeneous cause. The seed and the four great elements are the four parts that can produce one fruit together, so they have this name.
It is not like karma, which has the same acquisition that includes its causes and effects.
If the Saá¹ƒmitÄ«yas say that form does not cease moment by moment and has a temporary abiding,
when the seed has not yet produced the sprout, it is only one seed.
If discussing the production of the fruit in terms of the present moment, it is just producing the sprout.
If discussing it in terms of continuity, it also has the meaning of producing the stem, leaves, and so forth. The later stages are all like this.
Karma is not like this. Although karma itself ceases, there is a dharma of non-loss that remains, including its fruit and preventing it from being lost.
Now, I will just discuss wholesome precepts.
Precepts have a root, and the root has preliminary skillful means and correct skillful means.

There are three things in the preliminary skillful means: first, the great assembly is in harmony and allows for the acceptance of precepts; second, correctly begging for precepts; third, the time period.
As for the time period, one vows to end all evil for the duration of one's life.

The correct skillful means are the master explaining one motion and three proclamations for them, up to the completion of the third proclamation, one then obtains the protection of the wholesome of body and speech.

This wholesome is precisely the precepts, with the vowing mind and so forth taking it in, using this as the root, not extinguishing for the duration of one's life, from this point onward it continuously flows.
If one commits offenses in the interim, the precepts will no longer flow; if one repents and completes it, it will then flow again.
As for flow, it flows out from the root.

The good karma flowing out from a single moment of precepts also arises and ceases, and the second moment of precepts does not arise from this moment of precepts. It still flows out from the root and produces the second moment of precepts. The later arising ones can flow out from the root.
If it is the SarvÄstivÄda doctrine, there is a corresponding acquisition that binds it.
Although the good karma of precepts has arisen and passed away, the corresponding acquisition binds it and it remains in the past, and the bound result is in the future.
If it is the Saá¹ƒmitÄ«ya doctrine, when the good karma of precepts arises, it produces this good karma together with the dharma of non-loss.

They do not say that there is karma that can produce the essence of karma, which arises and passes away, and the dharma of non-loss does not cease, but rather it grasps the result of karma and prevents it from being lost.

The dharma of non-loss is not a dharma that ceases moment by moment, but rather a dharma that ceases when the time comes. It has the meaning of temporarily abiding, and its essence ceases only when the result is about to arise.
If it is the precepts of concentration, they all have the meaning of continuing to flow along with the root.
The object of giving is that the object always flows in goodness according to the object, but if it is a good without outflows, it cannot obtain the fruit.
There is no dharma of non-loss that arises together with goodness, and there is no flowing out in other minds. The good without outflows always flows.
Question:
The karma that arises together with the dharma of non-loss is a conditioned dharma. Why does the essence of karma cease while the dharma of non-loss does not cease?
Answer:
Goodness is a dharma associated with the mind, therefore it arises and immediately ceases.
The dharma of non-loss is not a dharma associated with the mind, therefore it does not cease moment by moment.

The meaning of the SarvÃ¢stivÄda is the same as that obtained by following. It also ceases moment by moment, but it is not a type of dharma associated with the mind. Its own continuity is uninterrupted.
Question:
How is the goodness of giving always flowing determined?
Answer:
The body and mouth are the essence of karma. The appearance is taken as bodily karma, and language is taken as verbal karma.
When one uses one's hands to take an object, either to take it or to lift it up and give it to another person, this is the form, and this form is taken as bodily action.
When one speaks and calls out to take a certain object and give it to a certain person, this speech is precisely verbal action.
There are three conditions that give rise to bodily and verbal actions:
First, the three roots of goodness;
Second, the correct thought that arises from the three roots of goodness;
Third, the intention that arises from correct thought, that is, the intention to give.
If we discuss this in general terms, these three conditions are used to give rise to bodily and verbal actions;
If we discuss this in terms of what is proximate, it is precisely the intention that gives rise to bodily and verbal actions.
As for giving, because these three conditions give rise to bodily and verbal actions, it is called the goodness of giving.
When a bodhisattva silently thinks and it rains treasures, mental action is also the action of giving.
There are three kinds of fields:
First, the field of blessings and virtues, such as Buddhas and bodhisattvas;
Second, the field of kindness and nurture, such as parents;
Third, the field of poverty refers to hungry and cold sentient beings, etc.
If one gives to a field of meritorious virtue, then the wholesome roots of non-delusion are many.
If one gives to a field of poverty, then the wholesome roots of non-delusion and non-hatred are many, because one must give rise to compassion towards poor sentient beings.
The wholesome roots of non-hatred are many. At one time, one is endowed with the three wholesome roots, following the field one faces, so there is no lack of differences in quantity.
Giving is also of two kinds:
First, respectful giving, second, beneficial giving.
If it is respectful, when giving, wholesome [roots] arise, and after giving, wholesomeness does not flow again.
The reason for this is, for example, if the Buddha has already entered Nirvana, one makes offerings of clothing, food, etc. out of respect for the Buddha.
Also, it is like worldly people making offerings of clothing, food, etc. to the Honored Ones of the past, because there is also respect.
Since there is no one to enjoy these things, wholesomeness cannot flow according to the situation.
Second, benefiting the giver means benefiting the four elements of the other person, because the other person's four elements grow by using this thing.
For one who gives for the sake of benefiting, goodness always flows according to the three things.
The three things are: first, the three roots of goodness;
second, other things;
third, sentient beings.
If any one of the three things is not complete, goodness will no longer flow.

If, for example, other things are not yet exhausted, but sentient beings are still using them, and the giver has already died or given rise to wrong views to cut off the roots of goodness, then goodness will have no root and will no longer flow.ğŸ”½If the giver is alive and the roots of goodness are unbroken, and the person who can use them has not yet perished, but the other things have already been exhausted, goodness will also no longer flow.

If the giver does not cut off the roots of goodness and also does not die, and the other things are also not yet exhausted, but the person who can use them has already passed away and there is no longer a person to use them, goodness will also no longer flow.
Although others may use it, it is not what the donor originally intended, and the merit of the gift will not accrue to them.
If the donor's intention is universal, then the merit will accrue to anyone who uses it.
Therefore, when those who are worthy of offerings receive donations, they should inform the donor. If they use it as they wish, then the merit of the gift will continue to increase endlessly.

If they do not do this and instead give it to others, it goes against the donor's intention. The person who diverts the gift not only loses the merit, but also incurs a sin, and in the future will fall into a bad realm to repay the debt.
This is not easy, so one should be careful.
Question:
When the roots of goodness are severed, since there are no more fundamental roots of goodness, how can goodness be produced again?
Answer:
This should be asked in two ways.

The first path of the stream-enterer is without outflows, and there are no outflows of the same kind as the fundamental roots. How can it be said that the arhat regresses and produces the afflictions that are eliminated by the path of cultivation?
How can afflictions arise without unwholesome roots as their basis?
Answer:
There are two kinds of causes for arising: the first is the prior cause, and the second is the co-arising cause.
The prior cause is precisely the three wholesome roots. Before doing good, there are these wholesome roots that can give rise to the good that is done, and therefore it is called the prior cause.

The co-arising cause refers to the arising of good due to the discernment of thought. When there is precisely discernment, that is the time when good arises, and therefore it is called the co-arising cause.
If the wholesome roots have not been severed, when doing good it arises from both causes.
If the wholesome roots have already been severed, when doing good it then only arises from the co-arising cause.
When good arises, it then connects with the three wholesome roots again, causing them to be associated with the wholesome mind.

Severing the wholesome roots does not mean that the substance of the wholesome roots is completely extinguished. It is precisely because of wrong views that they are separated and no longer associated with the wholesome mind, and this is called severing.
If the uncontaminated path arises, the substance of the contaminated wholesome roots then ceases.
For the stream-enterer, the initial uncontaminated path has not yet arisen before, and there are no uncontaminated wholesome roots, only arising from the innate.
When the arhat regresses and gives rise to afflictions, the three unwholesome roots have already been exhausted, and they also only arise from the innate cause.
Question:
Does the Buddha of the Lesser Vehicle receive offerings of food? When eating this food, does he defecate or urinate?
Answer:
The Buddha has no defecation or urination.

On both sides below the Buddha's chin, towards the neck, there are a thousand sinews each, which receive all the flavors of food. When the food reaches here, it immediately transforms into blood and flesh, thus there is no defecation or urination.
There are two interpretations regarding the wheel-turning king:
One says he has defecation and urination, one says he does not.
The three vehicles are the same as ordinary beings in having defecation and urination.
If the food of the six heavens is called sÅ«tra, sÅ« is translated as good, and dhÄ is translated as genuine and real, this food is refined and exquisite, and does not form defecation or urination.
The meaning of cessation is that there is no common bondage, because the complete exhaustion of common bondage is called cessation.

In the previous example, there should only be the latter phrase, but there is the former phrase. In India, nirvÄá¹‡a is called by ten names, one of which is nirvÄá¹‡a. Now, it shows that it explains the meaning of cessation and does not explain the other meanings, so it distinguishes it with the first phrase.
In the Madhyama Ä€gama there is the Sutra on Unbinding Bondage, which says: The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Craving and love are in your eyes, you must extinguish them.
If you extinguish craving and love, your eyes will also be extinguished. Because the eyes encounter form, craving and love arise, and consciousness is bound together.
Craving and love are the bondage of afflictions, while the eyes and form are the bondage of objects.
If the bondage of craving and love is extinguished, the bondage of the eyes and so forth will also be destroyed.
The sutra compares it to a person being chained with a lock and placed in a prison.
The chain is one bondage, the prison is one bondage.
If one removes the chain and burns the prison, then one is free from the two bonds.
The two bonds bind beings together, so it is said that they are bound together.
Liberation from craving is called purity, liberation from objects is called exhaustion, this is the nirvana with remainder and without remainder.
The cessation of craving is nirvana with remainder, the cessation of objects is nirvana without remainder.
Just as with the eyes, so it is with the ears, nose, etc.
Liberation from the three characteristics of conditioned phenomena is called tranquility.

There are two kinds of conditioned phenomena: one takes the three times as the three characteristics of conditioned phenomena, the other takes arising, aging, and ceasing as the three characteristics of conditioned phenomena.
The reason why abiding is not mentioned is that conditioned phenomena have no abiding, abiding is the characteristic of the unconditioned, therefore it is not discussed.
Because of wrong thoughts, afflictions arise, afflictions give rise to karma, karma gives rise to retribution, since there is a mutual arising of cause and effect, there are the three times;
Unconditioned dharmas have no cause and effect or arising, so they are not in the three times.
Conditioned dharmas originally do not exist, so they arise. Because they arise, they age and cease.
Unconditioned dharmas originally exist, so they do not arise. Because they do not arise, they do not age and cease.
Conditioned dharmas have both kinds of three characteristics, so they are agitated and not tranquil.
Unconditioned dharmas are liberated from these two kinds of three characteristics. Since they are not agitated, they are called tranquil.
Within one affliction there is one liberation, so within the ninety-eight afflictions there are ninety-eight liberations.
All dharmas are originally unborn. Being unborn is liberation.
Because sentient beings are deluded, they give rise to attachment to form and so forth. Because of attachment, karma arises. Karma gives rise to retribution.
Afflictions and attachment to form cannot accord with the principle of the unconditioned.

The unconditioned dharmas that are opposed to them are precisely this craving. If it is severed, one realizes and attains this unconditioned dharma. Therefore, the ninety-eight afflictions have ninety-eight unconditioned dharmas, and karma and its fruits follow.
The afflictions do not have separate unconditioned dharmas.
Because it is truly good, it is called wonderful.
There are four kinds of goodness: 1. True goodness, 2. Goodness by nature, 3. Goodness by association, 4. Goodness by production.
True goodness is precisely nirvÄá¹‡a.
Saá¹ƒsÄra is an evil dharma. NirvÄá¹‡a is without evil and does not arise from causes and conditions, so it is called true goodness.
Goodness by nature is precisely the three roots of goodness: non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion.
These three roots of goodness do not rely on other conditions. Their nature is able to counteract the three evils of greed, hatred, and delusion.
NirvÄá¹‡a is without the three evils. Because it is commensurate with nirvÄá¹‡a, it is called goodness.
It is analogous to the three medicines, which do not rely on other conditions. Their nature is able to cure illnesses:
Oil can cure wind disorders, ghee can cure heat disorders, and honey can cure flatulence.

The third type of good, that which is mixed with the three characteristics, is the good of mental action, because it arises in accordance with the three roots of goodness. It gives rise to faith, wisdom, and other good things.
When faith, wisdom, and other such things arise, the mind and mental factors that accompany them are all good because they are in accordance with the three roots of goodness.
When they are not yet mixed, the three roots of goodness each can cure one evil.
When the mind and mental factors that accompany it are not mixed with the three roots of goodness, they have no use in curing evil. When they are mixed, they are able to completely destroy all evils.
It is like when various medicines are not yet mixed together, each can cure illnesses. After they are mixed, there is nothing they cannot cure.
The fourth type of good, that which is initiated, is the good of body and speech.
The body and speech are originally not good, but because the good of mental action gives rise to body and speech, the body and speech give rise to good.
It is like water, which is originally not a medicine. When medicine is put into the water and boiled, the medicine gives rise to the water, causing the water to also become a medicine.
All three roots of goodness are accomplished as good because they accord with true goodness.
Evil is a coarse dharma.
The unconditioned has no evil and is true goodness, thus it is called excellent.
Question:
When the mind and mental factors are associated with the three roots of goodness, are they all associated with the three roots of goodness at the same time?
Answer:
They are all associated with the three roots of goodness at the same time.
When faith, wisdom, etc. are present, this mind attains the principle and is thus without delusion. Greed and anger do not arise and are thus without greed and anger.
Question:
When the mind and mental factors are associated with the three unwholesome roots, are they all associated with the three unwholesome roots at the same time?
Answer:
When an evil mind is present, this mind is contrary to principle and is always associated with ignorance.
When suffering is associated with greed, it is not associated with anger, because evil and good are mutually exclusive.
Question:
Are the three roots of goodness mental factors?
Answer:
Because they are not mental factors, sometimes they are not associated with the mind.
As the MahÄsÄá¹ƒghika and other schools say, the nature of sentient beings' minds is originally pure, defiled by adventitious dust.
Purity is precisely the three roots of goodness.
Sentient beings, from beginningless birth and death, have adventitious dust, which is precisely afflictions.
Afflictions are precisely the afflictions of latent tendencies, and the afflictions of latent tendencies are precisely the three roots of non-goodness.
Because there are three roots of goodness, faith, wisdom, and so forth arise. When faith, wisdom, and so forth arise, they support the three roots of goodness, so they are called associated.
Because there are three roots of non-goodness, non-good such as greed, hatred, and so forth arise. When non-good arises, it supports the three roots of non-good, so it is said to be associated.

If one gives rise to wrong views and severs the three roots of goodness, the three roots of goodness temporarily cease, not permanently. Later, if good arises, it will connect them and allow them to arise.
If one severs the three roots of non-goodness, severing them is permanent non-arising, the supreme cessation, called permanently separated.
It is like a person who is in the midst of enemies and cannot find peace;
If they have cut off the enemies, but have not gone far from them, then there is the meaning of peace, but it is not the most excellent peace;
If they have completely left their domain, then that is the most excellent peace.
The inner correspondence is also like this. If one is in the midst of the enemies of afflictions, then one has not found peace at all;
If one has already cut them off, but has not completely exhausted them, then there is the meaning of peace, but it is not the most excellent peace;
If one has completely cut them off and has permanently left the afflictions behind, then that is the most excellent peace.
Arhats have completely exhausted the afflictions and will never be reborn again. This is the most excellent peace.
Stream-enterers have completely exhausted the afflictions of views and will never be reborn again. This is also the most excellent peace.
In order to counteract the wrong paths, it is called the path.
The ninety-six kinds of Å›ramaá¹‡as all practice wrong paths.
Therefore, it is called the wrong path. Those who practice this path go nowhere, so it is called the wrong path.
If one practices the path of morality, concentration, and wisdom, one can attain nirvana.
In order to counteract the wrong path, morality, concentration, and wisdom are taught as the path.
Another explanation is that it is called the path because it can be sought.
Just as when a person intends to go to a certain place, they must first find the road;
if one wishes to seek liberation, one must first find the supramundane path.
Morality, concentration, and wisdom are the places that can be sought, so they are called the path.
It is called suchness because it counteracts non-suchness.
There are two explanations:
one clarifies countering non-suchness in principle, and the second clarifies countering non-suchness in practice.

The four inverted views are not in accord with principle, so they are non-suchness. Taking permanence, bliss, self, and purity and placing them in saá¹ƒsÄra, and taking impermanence, suffering, non-self, and impurity and placing them in nirvÄá¹‡a.

Now, contemplating that birth and death are impermanent, suffering, non-self, and impure, and that nirvana is permanent, blissful, self, and pure, being in accord with principle is precisely thusness.
Question:
How can the nirvana of the Lesser Vehicle be considered the self?
If it is the self, then all dharmas are not non-self.
Answer:
The Lesser Vehicle clarifies that there is no self within all dharmas, and therefore it is called non-self.
Nirvana has substance, and having substance is precisely the dharma-self.
As for the practice of counteracting that which is not as it should be, non-Buddhists have the views of eternalism and annihilationism.
Those with the view of eternalism think that the self does not perish, and in the future receives retribution.
In order to receive retribution in the future, they cultivate ascetic practices in the present, which amount to eleven things:
First, permanent sitting, always sitting without rising.
Second, great exertion, not staying still and avoiding the dangers of mountains and valleys, but wandering about.
Third, not eating, fasting and starving oneself.
Fourth, standing for a long time, always standing in one place.
Fifth, following the sun, one raises one's head to look up at the sun. In the morning, one looks to the east, following the sun as it rises and sets, watching without slackening.
Sixth, roasting, one should roast in the great heat of the day, roasting one's head with the sun and burning fires on all sides to roast one's body.
Seventh, sleeping on thorns, one takes thorns and places them in one place, sleeping on top of them.
Eighth, throwing oneself off a cliff.
Ninth, jumping into a fire.
Tenth, throwing oneself into water.
Eleventh, making offerings to the gods, one gouges out one's own sinews to make strings for a pipa and plays it as an offering to the gods in advance.
Those with the view of annihilation say that when the body perishes, the self also perishes, and there is no future or present. They do whatever they want and create various offenses.
These practices are not in accord with correct practice, so they are called incorrect practices.
Now, contemplating neither permanence nor annihilation, practicing the middle way that is in accord with the state of nirvana, is called correct practice.
The reason nirvana is called a country is because of two meanings:
First, it is because it is guarded by those with great power.
The powerful person is the Buddha, the solitary realizer, and the arhat, who have attained nirvana without fault, and are therefore called firm.
Second, because enemies and thieves do not invade.
Within nirvana, one is forever free from afflictions, which is precisely not being invaded.
There are three meanings for not planting affairs:
First, not being willing to leave, second, taking a wrong path, and third, doubting the path.
If one gives rise to the view of self, taking birth and death as the ultimate, and no longer striving to seek nirvana, this is the meaning of not being willing to leave.
Although one may wish to strive and seek, practicing the precepts is precisely taking a wrong path.
Not knowing which of the eight pure concentrations and the eight impure concentrations is correct is precisely doubting the path.
If one cultivates pure wisdom and distinguishes right from wrong, one will eliminate doubts about the path.
Having eliminated doubts about the path, one will also eliminate taking a wrong path.
Not clinging to birth and death is precisely eliminating the unwillingness to leave.
Cultivating pure wisdom can eliminate afflictions such as the view of self, attachment to precepts, and doubt.
Nirvana is free from afflictions, which is the matter corresponding to nirvana.
This matter is not wrong, so it is called right practice.
The remedy for all fears is called liberation.
As for all fears, the Buddha asked King Prasenajit:
Some say that there is a great mountain coming from the east, passing through the ground and reaching the sun.
In this way, it is said that there are great mountains coming from the other three directions.
What would you do now?
The king replied to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
This cannot be repelled by kind words, cannot be repelled by giving, cannot be repelled by frightening, cannot be repelled by raising troops, and is not within the scope of these four skillful means.
Now I can only single-mindedly and urgently cultivate the eightfold noble path to seek liberation.
The Buddha asked again:
If there is a fire coming to burn your head and burn your clothes,
Do you want to first extinguish the fire or first cultivate the eightfold noble path?
The king replied:
World-Honored One!
The fire is burning my head and clothes. If I extinguish the fire, it is only a temporary escape from suffering, not a permanent escape;
If I cultivate the eightfold noble path, I will permanently escape from suffering.
I should first cultivate the eightfold noble path, not first extinguish the fire.

The four mountains from the four directions are metaphors for the four sufferings of old age, sickness, death, and separation from what is loved. The suffering of old age can destroy youth, the suffering of sickness can deprive one of health, the suffering of death can overturn one's lifespan, and the suffering of separation from what is loved can disrupt wealth and happiness.
What came before are all different interpretations. The meaning upheld by Vasubandhu is the same as the meaning of the Upadeti-sastra.
The author of the treatise says:
I will now explain what I believe and understand.ğŸ”½Because there is arising and ceasing, it is called impermanent.
Because conditioned dharmas have arising and ceasing, they cannot be permanent.
Birth is existence, and cessation is non-existence. Since there is existence before and non-existence after, it is impermanent.
Why is birth not permanent birth, and why is cessation not permanent cessation, yet you say that birth and cessation are impermanent?
The explanation says:ğŸ”½Because birth destroys cessation, cessation is not permanent.
Because cessation also destroys birth, birth is also impermanent.
Because they have contradictory natures, they are called suffering.
The five aggregates are a mass of suffering, always going against the minds of sentient beings, causing them to experience suffering.

Sentient beings all love the bodies they receive, taking care of them with clothing, food and drink in various ways, but they do not know this kindness and always give rise to various sufferings, going against the minds of sentient beings. Between the increase and decrease of clothing and food, they always give rise to distress and desire to bring them peace.

The reason is that sitting for a long time gives rise to suffering, and after sitting for a while, one needs to walk. After walking for a long time, it also gives rise to suffering. In this way, the four deportments always go against each other.
The reason it always goes against the minds of sentient beings is because the objects it perceives are not real, and going against them produces suffering.
Because it is separated from substance, it is called emptiness.
All dharmas are provisional names, with names and meanings but no substance.
The ability to produce through combination is the meaning of cause, and the name of cause is established within combination.
That which is produced is the meaning of effect, and the name of effect is established within that which is produced.
But cause and effect have no substance.
Why is this so?
The combination of faculties and objects can produce consciousness. Apart from faculties and objects, is there any separate substance of cause?
Because of combination, it is said that consciousness is produced. Apart from combination, is there any separate substance of consciousness that is produced?
There is cause and effect, but no doer or function. There is no cause and effect, but there is the name and meaning of cause and effect.
As for no doer, the cause has no substance and no true ability to do.
As for no function, the effect has no substance and no reality.
The meaning of being able to experience suffering and joy is that there is no substance in the meaning, which is the meaning of being apart from substance, thus it is called emptiness.
Because there is no self-person, it is called no-self.
The Buddha said that there are dharmas that do not go beyond the eighteen realms. If one says there is a self, to which realm does it belong?
If it is not included in the eighteen realms, then one should know there is no self.
This refutes the meaning of the VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«ya school.
Their rescue argument says:
The self is present in the eighteen realms, how could it be made to be included in a separate realm?
The self they grasp is said to be neither the same nor different, it is an indescribable storehouse.
Now I will refute it further. The eye faculty and form objects are the objects, and eye consciousness is the subject. Because of the faculties and objects, consciousness arises.
Now I will first refute it within the objects.
The self is present in the faculties and objects, is it the same or different?
If it is different, then the object of cognition should have three factors: sense faculty, object, and self. Why did the Buddha only speak of two and not three?
If you say there is a self different from the sense faculties and objects, but the Buddha did not speak of it as the object of cognition, then this self is useless.
Moreover, if you say it is different from the sense faculties and objects, then your claim of non-difference is destroyed.
If you say the self is the same as the sense faculties and objects, then there are only sense faculties and objects, where is the self?
Then your claim of non-sameness is also destroyed.
Next, it is refuted in terms of the cognizing subject.
Is the self the same as or different from cognition?
If different, then the cognizing subject would have two aspects: self and cognition.
If there are two factors, why did the Buddha not speak of them?
If they exist but the Buddha did not speak of them, then the self is useless, and your claim of non-difference is destroyed.

If the self and consciousness were one, since consciousness arises from conditions and is conditioned, the self would also be conditioned. You assert that the self is neither conditioned nor unconditioned, but this statement would be destroyed.
Moreover, your statement that they are not one would also be destroyed.

If you refute the non-Buddhists' view of the self, the non-Buddhists establish the view of the self with four kinds of knowledge to prove the existence of the self: direct knowledge, inferential knowledge, knowledge by analogy, and knowledge from authoritative statements. Using these four kinds of knowledge, they prove the existence of the self.
The non-Buddhists have two views, annihilationism and eternalism. If it is the view of annihilationism, they say that this very body is the self, so when the body perishes, the self also perishes.
Since it is precisely the body, and the body is presently seen to exist, this is direct knowledge that there is a self.

If one sees the five characteristics such as exhalation and inhalation as being the characteristics of the self, since one sees its characteristics, one knows that there is a self. This is inferential knowledge that there is a self.
If one sees oneself as having a self and knows that others also have a self, this is the analogy of knowing that there is a self.
If one hears the holy teacher say that there is a self, one knows that there is a self. This is the sound knowledge of knowing that there is a self.
If one is a proponent of eternalism, then one only knows that there is a self through the two knowledges of inference and sound.
The proponents of eternalism say that atoms and the self cannot be seen and are not known by the knowledge of realization.
There are also proponents of eternalism who say that the self is known by the knowledge of realization.

They say that the white essence in the eye is the moon, the red essence in the middle of the white is the sun, the blue essence in the middle of the red is space, and the person's child in the blue essence is the self. The self is eternal, and this can also be seen, so it is known by the knowledge of realization.
